questions.text: Which of the following topical antifungal has both anti- inflammatory effects and anti-pruritic action? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sertaconazole

 

Sertaconazole has both anti-inflammatory effects and anti-pruritic action. It is used to treat dermatophytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that also has anti-androgenic effects. However, it does not possess notable anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic properties.

 

Option C. Luliconazole: Luliconazole is effective against dermatophytes and yeasts, but it does not have significant anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic actions.

 

Option D. Terbinafine: Terbinafine is mainly used to treat dermatophytosis. It does not have substantial anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of bipolar disorder has recently been started on lithium therapy. During a follow-up visit, the healthcare provider wants to educate the patient on the signs of lithium toxicity. Which of the following side effects should the patient be instructed to monitor and report immediately as they may indicate lithium toxicity? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ataxia and Diarrhea

 

Ataxia, tinnitus and diarrhea are common signs of lithium toxicity. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic range, meaning that the difference between a therapeutic dose and a toxic dose is small. Therefore, monitoring for signs of toxicity is crucial. Other signs of lithium toxicity can include tremors, confusion, and vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaise and sore throat: While these symptoms can be concerning, they are not typically associated with lithium toxicity. They might be indicative of an infection or other unrelated conditions.

 

Option C. Fever: Fever is not a common sign of lithium toxicity. It may indicate an infection or other illness.

 

Option D. Breathlessness: This symptom is not typically associated with lithium toxicity. Breathlessness might be related to other medical conditions such as respiratory or cardiac issues.

 

Therefore, patients on lithium therapy should be particularly vigilant for symptoms like ataxia and diarrhea, as they could indicate the onset of lithium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients on lithium therapy should be educated to monitor and immediately report signs of lithium toxicity, such as ataxia and diarrhea, to prevent serious adverse effects.

 

Mnemonic

 

If DAT symptom is present, report to hospital:

 

  • Diarrhea
  • Ataxia
  • Tinnitus

questions.text: A psychiatric patient was started on lithium for the management of bipolar disorder. To monitor the blood lithium levels, at what time interval should the blood sample be collected after the administration of lithium tablets? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. After 12 hours

 

Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index; therefore, the blood levels of lithium have to be monitored. Blood samples to measure lithium levels are typically collected 12 hours after the last dose. This timing is chosen because it represents the 'trough' level – the lowest concentration of the drug in the bloodstream before the next dose is due. Measuring at this point helps to ensure that the lithium level stays within the therapeutic range and avoids toxicity.

 

Plasma Levels of Lithium:

 

  • For prophylaxis of mania – 0.5 – 0.7 mEq/L
  • For acute mania – 0.8 – 1.2 mEq/L
  • Toxicity is seen when it is > 1.5 mEq/L
  • Dialysis is required at levels >4 mEq/L

 

Educational Objective:

 

To monitor lithium levels accurately and ensure they remain within the therapeutic range, blood samples should be collected 12 hours after the last dose. This helps in avoiding toxicity and ensuring the efficacy of the treatment for bipolar disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following is a second line anti-tubercular drug? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethionamide

 

Ethionamide is used as a second-line treatment for tuberculosis (TB), particularly in cases of multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB), when the first-line drugs (like isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide) are not effective or cannot be used due to resistance or side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: This is a first-line anti-tubercular drug, widely used in the treatment of both latent and active TB infections.

 

Option C. Acyclovir: Acyclovir is an antiviral medication, primarily used for the treatment of herpes simplex virus infections and not for tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Vancomycin: Vancomycin is an antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections caused by gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It is not used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethionamide is a second-line anti-tubercular drug used in the management of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), whereas isoniazid is a first-line drug, and acyclovir and vancomycin are not used for tuberculosis treatment.

questions.text: Most commonly implicated drug for causation of acute liver failure is? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paracetamol

 

  • All the four drugs given Paracetamol, Valproate, Warfarin and Tetracyclines can cause hepatotoxicity. Paracetamol among these is the most common cause particularly in patients with liver disease and in alcoholics.
  • Paracetamol is the most common cause of acute liver failure in many countries, particularly in the context of overdose. It can cause severe hepatotoxicity, which can lead to acute liver failure, especially when taken in doses exceeding recommended levels or in individuals with certain risk factors (such as existing liver disease and chronic alcohol use etc.).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate: While valproate can cause hepatotoxicity, it is less commonly associated with acute liver failure compared to paracetamol. It is more frequently a concern in certain populations, such as young children and individuals on multiple anticonvulsants.

 

Option C. Warfarin: Warfarin is an anticoagulant and is not commonly associated with acute liver failure. Its primary risk is bleeding due to its anticoagulant effects.

 

Option D. Tetracycline: High doses of tetracycline, especially the older formulations, can cause liver toxicity, but it is not the most common drug causing acute liver failure. Tetracycline-induced liver injury is now relatively rare due to the decreased use of high-dose intravenous forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is the most common drug implicated in the causation of acute liver failure, especially in the context of overdose and in individuals with risk factors like existing liver disease and chronic alcohol use.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/223

choices.text: 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D
1-D, 2-F, 3-E, 4-C

1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

questions.text: Match the following drugs with their ocular adverse effects?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

 

The following are the drugs and their associated ocular adverse effects:

 

  1. Amiodarone: This drug is known to cause corneal deposits (cornea verticillata) and optic neuritis. The correct match for Amiodarone is D (Optic neuritis).
  2. Hydroxychloroquine: This drug is associated with bull’s eye maculopathy, a specific type of retinopathy. Therefore, Hydroxychloroquine is correctly matched with C (Retinopathy).
  3. Systemic steroids: When given topically, systemic steroids can cause open-angle glaucoma. However, when given systemically, they are known to cause posterior subcapsular cataract. Thus, systemic steroids are best matched with F (Cataract).
  4. Digoxin: This drug can cause yellow vision, a condition where the patient perceives a yellow tint in their vision. Hence, Digoxin is correctly matched with E (Yellow vision).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular adverse-effects of drugs:

 

  • Amiodarone: Corneal deposits (cornea verticallata) Optic neuritis
  • Hydroxychloroquine: Bull’s eye maculopathy (retinopathy).
  • Systemic steroids: Given topically – cause Open angle Glaucoma; Given systemically – cause Posterior subcapsular cataract.
  • Digoxin: Yellow vision

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/880, 318, 560, Goodman Gilman 13th/  564

choices.text: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid

questions.text: Which of the following is the antidote for fibrinolytic therapy? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid


Fibrinolytic therapy involves the use of drugs (like alteplase, streptokinase, etc.) to break down blood clots. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA) and tranexamic acid are antifibrinolytic agents that can be used to counteract bleeding due to excessive fibrinolysis, which can occur during or after fibrinolytic therapy. These work by inhibiting plasminogen activators and, to a lesser degree, plasmin activity, thereby reducing the breakdown of fibrin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine Sulphate: This is used as an antidote for heparin overdose, not for fibrinolytic therapy. Protamine sulphate binds to and inactivates heparin.

 

Option B. Dalteparin: Dalteparin is a low molecular weight heparin and is an anticoagulant itself. It is not used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy.

 

Option D. Alteplase: Alteplase is a fibrinolytic agent, not an antidote. It is used to dissolve blood clots in conditions like acute ischemic stroke, pulmonary embolism, and myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is the antidote for fibrinolytic therapy, used to counteract excessive bleeding due to fibrinolysis. It works by inhibiting plasminogen activators and stabilizing clots.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not need dose adjustment in renal failure? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linagliptin

 

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. Unlike other DPP-4 inhibitors, linagliptin is primarily excreted via the enterohepatic system, with only a small fraction eliminated by the kidneys. Therefore, it does not require dose adjustments in patients with renal impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: This DPP-4 inhibitor is primarily excreted by the kidneys, and its dose usually needs to be adjusted in patients with renal impairment.

 

Option B. Saxagliptin: Saxagliptin and its active metabolite are primarily eliminated by the kidneys, necessitating dose adjustments in patients with renal failure.

 

Option C. Vildagliptin: Vildagliptin is partially excreted by the kidneys, and dose adjustment is recommended in patients with moderate to severe renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin is a unique DPP-4 inhibitor that does not require dose adjustments in patients with renal failure due to its primary excretion via the enterohepatic system. This makes it an advantageous option for managing type 2 diabetes in patients with compromised renal function.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drug is not bactericidal? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thioacetazone

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug. Bacteriostatic drugs inhibit the growth and replication of bacteria, rather than killing them outright. Thioacetazone is less commonly used nowadays due to its side effects and the availability of more effective treatments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is a bactericidal drug against actively dividing Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the bacterial cell wall.

 

Option B. Rifapentin: Rifapentin is a bactericidal antibiotic and is a derivative of rifampicin. It works by inhibiting bacterial RNA synthesis and is used primarily in the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Kanamycin: Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and is bactericidal. It works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. It is used as a second-line drug for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug, which means it inhibits bacterial growth rather than killing the bacteria outright. In contrast, isoniazid, rifapentin, and kanamycin are all bactericidal drugs used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

choices.text: 1-F, 2- E, 3-D, 4- B
1-F, 2-E, 3-B, 4-A

questions.text: Match the following drugs poisoning with the antidotes:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-F, 2-E, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. HCN (Hydrogen Cyanide):

 

  • Antidote: F. Amyl nitrite
    HCN poisoning, also known as cyanide poisoning, is treated with amyl nitrite, which induces methemoglobinemia, allowing cyanide to bind to methemoglobin instead of cytochrome oxidase, reducing its toxicity. The DOC for cyanide poisoning is Hydroxocobalamine.

 

2. Paracetamol (Acetaminophen):

 

  • Antidote: E. N-acetylcysteine
    N-acetylcysteine replenishes glutathione stores, helping detoxify the reactive metabolite of paracetamol, thereby preventing liver damage.

 

3. Morphine:

 

  • Antidote: B. Nalorphine
    Nalorphine is an opioid antagonist used to counteract the effects of opioid overdose, including morphine.

 

4. Nicotine:

 

  • Antidote: A. Trimethadione
    Trimethadione is used in cases of nicotine poisoning due to its ganglionic blocking properties, similar to the Nn receptor blockers (ganglionic blockers) like Trimethaphan and Hexamethonium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HCN poisoning: DOC is Hydroxocobalamin. Amyl Nitrite(inhalational) with sodium thiosulphate (iv) can also be used.
  • Paracetamol poisoning (causes hepatoxicity): N-acetylcysteine is used.
  • Morphine poisoning: DOC is Naloxone. Nalorphine can also be used.
  • Nicotine poisoning: Trimethaphan and Hexamethonium – Nn receptor blockers

(ganglionic blockers) are used.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/590, 223, 509, 134

choices.text: 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intramuscular route
0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intravenous route
0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intramuscular route
0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intravenous route

questions.text: A patient was given ampicillin 2 g intravenously. After that, the person developed rash on skin, hypotension and difficulty in breathing. The patient should be managed by? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intramuscular route

 

Penicillin’s are prone to cause allergic reactions. Features like rash on skin, hypotension, and difficulty in breathing are suggestive of anaphylactic shock.

 

In case of anaphylactic shock the resuscitation council of UK has recommended the following measures:

 

  • Put the patient in reclining position, administer oxygen at high flow rate and perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation if required.
  • Inject adrenaline 0.5 mg (0.5 ml of 1 in 1000 for adult, 0.3 ml for child 6-12 years and 0.15 ml for child upto 6 years) i.m.; repeat every 5-10 min in case patient does not improve or improvement is transient. This is the only life saving measure. Adrenaline should not be injected i.v. (can itself be fatal) unless shock is immediately life threatening. If adrenaline is to be injected i. v., it should be diluted to 1:10,000 and infused slowly with constant monitoring.
  • Administer a H1 antihistaminic (pheniramine 20-40 mg or chlorpheniramine 10-20 mg) i.m./slow i.v. It may have adjuvant value.
  • Intravenous glucocorticoid (hydrocortisone sod. succinate 200 mg) should be added in severe/recurrent cases. It acts slowly but is especially valuable for prolonged reactions and in asthmatics. It may be followed by oral prednisolone for 3 days.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 97

choices.text: Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax
Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy
Treatment of severe falciparum malaria
Treatment of endemic malaria in children < 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following is clinical use of tafenoquine? (AIIMS Nov 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax

 

Radical cure – Several patients of P. vivax malaria relapse due to persistence of exo-erythrocytic stage. Drugs which attack this stage (hypnozooites) given together with a clinical curative achieve total eradication of the parasite from the patient's body.

 

Drug of choice for radical cure of vivax and ovale malaria is:

 

  • Primaquine 15 mg daily for 14 days
  • Tafenoquine is a new long-acting exo-erythrocytic schizontocidal drug. It has been developed as a single dose radical cure for vivax malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy: Tafenoquine is not recommended for malaria prophylaxis in pregnancy due to its potential for causing hemolysis in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Pregnant women are typically advised to use other antimalarial drugs for prophylaxis.

 

Option C. Treatment of severe falciparum malaria: The treatment of severe falciparum malaria typically involves intravenous administration of drugs like artesunate or quinine, rather than tafenoquine. Tafenoquine is not used in this context.

 

Option D. Treatment of endemic malaria in children < 2 years: Tafenoquine is not recommended for use in children under 2 years of age. The safety and efficacy of tafenoquine in this age group have not been established, and alternative antimalarial therapies are preferred for young children.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tafenoquine is used for the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax malaria due to its long-acting effects against the exo-erythrocytic stage of the parasite, helping to prevent relapses.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 878

choices.text: Peripheral neuropathy is a common adverse effect
It is active against gram positive organisms
It has poor oral bioavailability
Major mode of elimination is renal excretion

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tedizolid is true? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is active against gram positive organisms

 

Tedizolid is an oxazolidinone-class antibiotic, similar to linezolid, and is primarily used to treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria.

 

Activity Against Gram-Positive Organisms: Tedizolid is particularly effective against gram-positive pathogens, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA). It works by inhibiting protein synthesis through binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peripheral neuropathy is a common adverse effect: Peripheral neuropathy and lactic acidosis are potential adverse effects of tedizolid, but they are not common.

 

Option C. It has poor oral bioavailability: This is incorrect. Tedizolid has very good oral bioavailability, nearly 90%, making it effective when administered orally.

 

Option D. Major mode of elimination is renal excretion: This is incorrect. Tedizolid is primarily metabolized in the liver, and renal excretion is not the major route of elimination.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tedizolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor that is primarily active against gram-positive organisms, including resistant strains like MRSA and VRSA. It has good oral bioavailability and is primarily metabolized in the liver.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/808

choices.text: Herbal medication with no effect known
Sham surgery
Cognitive behavioral therapy

questions.text: Which one of the following is a placebo? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sham surgery

 

Sham surgery (placebo surgery) is a fictitious surgical intervention when the actual step that is of therapeutic benefit is omitted. For example, opening the abdomen and then again suturing it without any sort of intervention done on the viscera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herbal medication with no effect known: While an herbal medication with no known effect might be considered a placebo in certain contexts, it is not specifically designed as a placebo. It could contain active ingredients with unknown effects.

 

Option B. Physiotherapy: Physiotherapy is an established therapeutic practice with known benefits for various conditions. It is not a placebo.

 

Option D. Cognitive behavioral therapy: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a well-established psychological treatment for a variety of mental health conditions. It is not a placebo, as it involves specific therapeutic techniques aimed at changing maladaptive thinking and behavior patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sham surgery is a type of placebo where the therapeutic intervention is omitted, used primarily in clinical trials to control for the placebo effect and test the efficacy of surgical procedures.

choices.text: Low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be useful in a patient with severe COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Favipiravir

 

Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that has been studied for use in COVID-19, but its effectiveness, particularly in severe cases, is less clear compared to other treatments. Favipiravir is known to work against RNA viruses, but its role in the treatment of severe COVID-19 has not been established as a standard of care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Patients with severe COVID-19 are at increased risk of thromboembolic events. LMWH is used to prevent blood clots and is an important part of the management of hospitalized COVID-19 patients, especially those with severe disease.

 

Option B. Oxygen: Oxygen therapy is crucial for patients with severe COVID-19, especially those experiencing respiratory distress and hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels). It is a key supportive treatment.

 

Option D. Steroids: Corticosteroids like dexamethasone have been shown to reduce mortality in patients with severe and critical COVID-19, particularly those requiring respiratory support. They are used to reduce inflammation in the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Favipiravir is least likely to be useful in a patient with severe COVID-19 compared to low molecular weight heparin, oxygen, and steroids, which have well-established roles in managing severe cases of the disease.

choices.text: Should not be used due to risk of addiction
Can be used as both have different mechanism of action
Should not be used as it is irrational
Can be used to treat cough effectively

questions.text: If Codeine is coming to the market in combination with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive, this combination? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Should not be used as it is irrational

 

  • Codeine is an opioid agonist and Dextromethorphan is a centrally acting NMDA receptor antagonist. Both codeine and dextromethorphan are antitussives, but they work through similar central mechanisms to suppress cough. Combining them does not offer additional therapeutic benefits but can increase the risk of side effects
  • A rational fixed dose drug combination would be to combine one centrally acting anti-tussive (either codeine or dextromethorphan) with expectorants (like potassium iodide, Guaifenesin), antihistaminic and mucolytics like (Ambroxol, Bromhexine, Acetyl cysteine)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Should not be used due to risk of addiction: While codeine has a potential for addiction, the main concern with this combination is not solely the risk of addiction but the lack of rationality in combining two centrally acting antitussives.

 

Option B. Can be used as both have different mechanisms of action: This is incorrect. Codeine and dextromethorphan both act centrally to suppress cough, and their mechanisms are similar enough that combining them does not provide a significant therapeutic advantage.

 

Option D. Can be used to treat cough effectively: Although both drugs are effective cough suppressants individually, their combination is not advisable due to the redundancy in action and increased risk of side effects without additional therapeutic benefit.

 

Therefore, the most accurate answer is C. The combination should not be used as it is irrational due to the overlapping mechanisms of action and increased risk of adverse effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combining codeine with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive is irrational due to their overlapping mechanisms of action and the increased risk of side effects without additional therapeutic benefit. Rational combinations for cough treatment involve combining one centrally acting antitussive with expectorants, antihistamines, and mucolytics.

choices.text: 1-A, 2-C, 3-C, 4-D
1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-E
1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-F
1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-F

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the organism they are used for? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-F

 

The correct matches based on the given drugs and organisms:

 

  1. Praziquantal: This drug is primarily used for the treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm). Therefore, the correct match for Praziquantal is D (Tapeworms).
  2. Di Ethyl Carbamezine: This drug is the drug of choice for the treatment of filariasis, making A (Filaria) the correct match.
  3. Nitazoxanide: This drug is used for Cryptosporidium and also for Giardia. However, the drug of choice for Giardia is metronidazole or tinidazole, but Nitazoxanide is also effective against Giardia. Therefore, the correct match for Nitazoxanide is B (Giardia).
  4. Mebendazole: This drug is used for treating various nematodes, including Ascaris lumbricoides. Therefore, the correct match for Mebendazole is F (Ascaris lumbricoides).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug of choice for treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm) is Praziquantal.
    • Drug of choice for treatment of liver fluke is triclabendazole.
    • Drug of choice for dog tapeworm (Echinococcus) is albendazole
  • Drug of choice for all nematodes (see exceptions below) is albendazole (or Mebendazole)
    • Drug of choice for treatment of filariasis is Diethylcarbamazine.
    • Drug of choice for treatment of Onchocerca and Strongyloides is ivermectin.
  • Nitazoxanide: DOC for Cryptosporidium and also used for Giardia (DOC is metronidazole and tinidazole)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/907

questions.text: The drug that decreases the size of prostate is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Finasteride

 

Finasteride: It inhibits the conversion of testosterone into its active form, DHT (dihydrotestosterone), by acting as a competitive inhibitor of the 5-reductase enzyme. It has a long-term effect of reducing prostatic epithelial cell proliferation, which reduces the size of the prostate and improves urine flow.

 

Tamsulosin is a Selective α1A Antagonist which dilates prostatic urethra and hence produces immediate symptom relief in BPH. It has no effect on reducing size of the prostate.

 

Flutamide is a Androgen Receptor antagonist with no hormonal activity. It is used for the treatment of metastatic prostatic cancer in conjunction with GnRH agonists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tamsulosin: Tamsulosin is a selective alpha-1A adrenergic receptor antagonist. It works by relaxing the muscles in the prostate and bladder neck, making it easier to urinate. While it provides symptomatic relief for BPH, it does not reduce the size of the prostate.

 

Option B. Sildenafil: Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitor used primarily for the treatment of erectile dysfunction. It has no effect on prostate size.

 

Option D. Flutamide: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of metastatic prostate cancer. It does not reduce the size of the prostate but works by blocking the effects of androgens (male hormones).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Finasteride decreases the size of the prostate by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), thereby reducing prostatic cell proliferation and improving urinary symptoms in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of sodium nitroprusside? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Stimulation of guanylyl cyclase

 

Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator that works by stimulating guanylyl cyclase. When sodium nitroprusside enters the bloodstream, it rapidly releases nitric oxide (NO). This NO then activates guanylyl cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells. The activation of guanylyl cyclase increases the conversion of GTP to cyclic GMP (cGMP). Elevated levels of cGMP lead to the dephosphorylation of myosin light chains, resulting in relaxation of vascular smooth muscle and subsequent vasodilation. This mechanism effectively reduces blood pressure and is used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and severe heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased cAMP: Drugs that increase cAMP, such as beta-adrenergic agonists, work through different mechanisms involving the activation of adenylate cyclase, not guanylyl cyclase. cAMP primarily mediates actions like increased heart rate and bronchodilation, which is not the primary action of sodium nitroprusside.

 

Option C. Calcium channel blockage: Calcium channel blockers, such as verapamil and diltiazem, inhibit the influx of calcium ions into cardiac and smooth muscle cells, leading to muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Sodium nitroprusside does not act through this pathway.

 

Option D. K+ channel opener: Potassium channel openers, such as minoxidil, work by hyperpolarizing the cell membrane, leading to relaxation of vascular smooth muscle. This is not the mechanism of action of sodium nitroprusside.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium nitroprusside acts by stimulating guanylyl cyclase, which leads to an increase in cGMP, causing relaxation of vascular smooth muscle and vasodilation. This makes it effective in rapidly reducing blood pressure in hypertensive emergencies.

choices.text: Transmembrane receptor linked to tyrosine kinase
Nuclear receptor
Ion channel receptor
G protein coupled receptor

questions.text: Levothyroxine/liothyronine acts by binding to thyroid receptors. Thyroid hormone receptors belong to which of the following class of receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Nuclear receptor

 

Thyroid hormone receptors (TRs) are part of the nuclear receptor superfamily. These receptors are located intracellularly, primarily within the nucleus, and function as transcription factors that regulate gene expression. When thyroid hormones (such as levothyroxine and liothyronine) enter the cell, they bind to these nuclear receptors. The hormone-receptor complex then binds to specific DNA sequences in the promoter regions of target genes, leading to modulation of gene transcription and subsequent protein synthesis. This process is crucial for the regulation of metabolism, growth, and development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmembrane receptor linked to tyrosine kinase: This class includes receptors such as the insulin receptor and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). These receptors span the cell membrane and, upon ligand binding, activate tyrosine kinase activity leading to a cascade of intracellular signaling events. Thyroid hormone receptors do not belong to this class.

 

Option C. Ion channel receptor: Ion channel receptors, also known as ligand-gated ion channels, open or close in response to the binding of a chemical messenger (ligand), such as neurotransmitters. Examples include the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor and GABA receptor. Thyroid hormone receptors do not function in this manner.

 

Option D. G protein coupled receptor: G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are membrane receptors that, upon ligand binding, activate G proteins which then trigger various intracellular signaling pathways. Examples include adrenergic receptors and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. Thyroid hormone receptors are not GPCRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid hormone receptors are intracellular and intranuclear receptors. They primarily function as transcription factors and directly interact with the genomic DNA to regulate gene expression.

 

Other examples of intranuclear receptors include Vitamin A and Vitamin D receptors.

choices.text: Discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm
Discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation
Discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent

questions.text: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, 2018 was awarded to James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo for which of the following discoveries? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation

 

The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2018 was awarded jointly to James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo for their pioneering work in cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation. Their research focused on understanding how the immune system can be harnessed to fight cancer, specifically through the mechanism of immune checkpoint inhibitors.

 

  • James P. Allison discovered that the protein CTLA-4 (cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4) acts as a brake on T cells. By inhibiting CTLA-4, it is possible to boost the immune system's response against cancer cells.
  • Tasuku Honjo discovered a different protein, PD-1 (programmed cell death protein 1), which also functions as an immune checkpoint. Blocking PD-1 can similarly enhance the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells.

 

These discoveries have led to the development of drugs known as immune checkpoint inhibitors, which have significantly improved treatment outcomes for various types of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discovery of mechanisms of autophagy: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2016 was awarded to Yoshinori Ohsumi for his discoveries of mechanisms for autophagy, a fundamental process for degrading and recycling cellular components.

 

Option B. Discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2017 was awarded to Jeffrey C. Hall, Michael Rosbash, and Michael W. Young for their discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm.

 

Option D. Discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2012 was awarded to John B. Gurdon and Shinya Yamanaka for the discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immune checkpoint inhibitors function by blocking the proteins that control the immune system's reactions to cancer cells. The immune system's brake is removed when these proteins are inhibited, making it easier for T cells to more efficiently eliminate cancer cells.

 

James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo were awarded the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for their discovery of cancer therapy through inhibition of negative immune regulation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not require dose reduction in patients with renal failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Doxycycline

 

Doxycycline is an antibiotic that does not require dose adjustment in patients with renal failure because it is primarily excreted in the bile and not significantly through the kidneys. This makes it safer for use in patients with impaired renal function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gentamicin: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that is primarily excreted by the kidneys. In patients with renal failure, the clearance of gentamicin is significantly reduced, and therefore, dose adjustments are necessary to avoid toxicity, particularly nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option B. Vancomycin: Vancomycin is an antibiotic that is also primarily excreted by the kidneys. In patients with renal impairment, dose adjustments are required to prevent accumulation of the drug and subsequent nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication that can cause nephrotoxicity. Although its dose does not typically require adjustment based solely on renal function, careful monitoring and possible dose adjustment are often necessary to manage its renal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drugs which are secreted in bile and safe in renal disease include:

 

Cef in: Cefoperazone, Ceftriaxone

 

The: Tigecycline

 

R: Rifampicin

 

E: Erythromycin

 

N: Nafcillin

 

A: Ampicillin

 

L: Lincosamide (Clindamycin)

 

D: Doxycycline

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not increase the risk of bleeding in patients undergoing warfarin therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Carbamazepine

 

Warfarin is an anticoagulant that is metabolized primarily by the CYP2C9 enzyme. The risk of bleeding with warfarin therapy is influenced by drugs that either inhibit or induce the metabolism of warfarin.

 

Carbamazepine, is an enzyme inducer. It induces CYP450 enzymes, including CYP2C9, which increases the metabolism of warfarin, leading to reduced plasma warfarin levels and a decreased anticoagulant effect. Therefore, carbamazepine does not increase the risk of bleeding; instead, it can reduce the effectiveness of warfarin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cimetidine: Cimetidine is a known inhibitor of the CYP450 enzymes, including CYP2C9. By inhibiting this enzyme, cimetidine reduces the metabolism of warfarin, leading to higher plasma concentrations of warfarin and an increased risk of bleeding.

 

Option C. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is an inhibitor of several CYP450 enzymes, including CYP2C9. This inhibition can lead to decreased metabolism of warfarin, increased plasma warfarin levels, and a higher risk of bleeding.

 

Option D. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is a potent inhibitor of CYP2C9. It reduces the metabolism of warfarin, resulting in elevated levels of warfarin in the blood and an increased risk of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs like Cimetidine, Isoniazid, Amiodarone, Clopidogrel, Ketoconazole, Verapamil etc inhibit the enzyme, thus reducing the metabolism of warfarin. This increases the plasma concentration of Warfarin and leads to increased risk of bleeding.

 

Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer and increases the metabolism of warfarin leading to decrease in effect of warfarin.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in acute mountain sickness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acetazolamide

 

Acetazolamide is the drug of choice for acute mountain sickness. Rapid ascent to high altitudes can lead to the development of headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, breathlessness etc. The underlying cause that has been implicated in its causation is cerebral edema. The low PO2 at high altitude causes arteriolar dilation, and if cerebral autoregulation does not compensate, there is an increase in capillary pressure that favors increased transudation of fluid into brain tissue leading to cerebral edema.

 

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that leads to metabolic acidosis, which in turn stimulates hyperventilation, leading to CO2 washout, and it helps in reducing the formation of CSF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid and can be used as a treatment for cerebral edema and severe cases of AMS. However, it is not the first-line drug of choice for general AMS prevention or mild cases.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used primarily for heart conditions such as atrial fibrillation and heart failure. It has no role in the prevention or treatment of acute mountain sickness.

 

Option C. Diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used for treating hypertension and angina. It is not used in the management of acute mountain sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetazolamide is the drug of choice for acute mountain sickness because it induces metabolic acidosis and stimulates hyperventilation, helping to improve oxygenation and reduce cerebral edema.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is associated with ophthalmic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is a first-line anti-tubercular drug used in combination with other medications to treat tuberculosis. One of its significant side effects is ophthalmic toxicity, specifically optic neuritis.

 

Ethambutol inhibits the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, which is necessary for the synthesis of the mycobacterial cell wall.

 

Ophthalmic Toxicity:

 

  • Optic Neuritis: Ethambutol can cause inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision problems.
  • Symptoms: Patients may experience blurred vision, loss of visual acuity, and difficulty distinguishing between red and green colors (red-green color blindness).
  • Monitoring: It is crucial to monitor visual acuity and color vision regularly in patients taking ethambutol. Any signs of visual impairment should prompt immediate cessation of the drug and consultation with an ophthalmologist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is another first-line anti-tubercular drug. Its main side effects include hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy, but it is not commonly associated with ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Option C. Kanamycin: Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used as a second-line treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). It is associated with ototoxicity (hearing loss) and nephrotoxicity, not ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Option D. Rifampin: Rifampin is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that can cause hepatotoxicity and discoloration of bodily fluids (e.g., urine, tears) to an orange-red color. It is not typically associated with ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is a first line anti tubercular drug that can cause optic neuritis and red green color blindness.

questions.text: A patient with diabetic macular edema developed glaucoma. Which of the following drugs would you consider giving last?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Prostaglandin analogues

 

Prostaglandin analogues are effective drugs for reducing intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor through the uveoscleral pathway. However, they can also cause side effects that might exacerbate conditions like macular edema, which is a consideration in this patient who has diabetic macular edema.

 

Side Effects of Prostaglandin Analogues:

 

  • Cystoid Macular Edema: This is a known side effect of prostaglandin analogues and can worsen the existing macular edema in a diabetic patient.
  • Iris Hyperpigmentation: This is generally a cosmetic issue but can be a concern for some patients.
  • Hypertrichosis: This involves increased growth of eyelashes, which is usually considered a benign side effect.

 

Given the risk of exacerbating macular edema, prostaglandin analogues should be considered last in the treatment plan for this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta Blockers:

 

  • Mechanism: Beta blockers like timolol reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing the production of aqueous humor.
  • Side Effects: They are generally well-tolerated in glaucoma treatment and do not exacerbate macular edema. Common side effects include bradycardia and bronchospasm, especially in patients with pre-existing respiratory conditions.

 

Option B. Alpha agonist:

 

  • Mechanism: Alpha agonists such as brimonidine reduce aqueous humor production and increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Side Effects: These drugs can cause dry mouth, fatigue, and ocular allergies, but they do not significantly affect macular edema.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine:

 

  • Mechanism: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent that increases aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork.
  • Side Effects: It can cause miosis, accommodative spasm, and brow ache. Pilocarpine does not exacerbate macular edema but is less commonly used due to its side effect profile and the need for frequent dosing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoid Macular edema is one of the side effects of Prostaglandin analogues. The other side effects are Iris hyperpigmentation and hypertrichosis of the eye lashes.

choices.text: Delayed diastolic depolarization
Increase in plateau
Decrease in preload
Increase in afterload

questions.text: What is the mechanism by which acetylcholine causes a decrease in the heart rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Delayed diastolic depolarization

 

Acetylcholine decreases heart rate by acting on muscarinic M2 receptors present in the sinoatrial (SA) node of the heart. The key mechanism involves:

 

  • Activation of M2 Receptors: When acetylcholine binds to M2 receptors, it activates a G-protein coupled pathway.
  • Opening of Potassium Channels: This leads to the opening of specific potassium channels (GIRK channels) resulting in an increased efflux of potassium ions from the SA node cells.
  • Hyperpolarization: The efflux of potassium causes hyperpolarization of the cell membrane, making it more negative.
  • Delayed Diastolic Depolarization: This hyperpolarization delays the diastolic depolarization phase, slowing the rate at which the SA node reaches the threshold potential to initiate the next action potential.
  • Result: The overall effect is a reduction in the heart rate (negative chronotropy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in Plateau:

 

  • Mechanism: An increase in the plateau phase would generally refer to the action of calcium channels during the action potential of myocardial cells, not the SA node. This mechanism is more related to the contractile cells rather than pacemaker cells.
  • Effect: This does not directly influence heart rate but can affect the force of contraction.

 

Option C. Decrease in Preload:

 

  • Mechanism: Preload refers to the end-diastolic volume in the ventricles. While changes in preload can influence stroke volume and cardiac output, they are not directly related to the rate control mechanisms mediated by acetylcholine.

 

Option D. Increase in Afterload:

 

  • Mechanism: Afterload refers to the resistance the heart must pump against, primarily influenced by systemic vascular resistance. This is not directly influenced by acetylcholine's action on the SA node and does not explain the decrease in heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The acetylcholine acts on the M2 receptor present on the SA node. This opens a special set of potassium channels causing an efflux of potassium (kAch) which hyperpolarizes the SA node. This leads to delayed depolarization of the SA node during ventricular diastole, thus leading to a slow heart rate.

choices.text: Decrease in Vmax
Decrease in Km
Decrease in both Km and Vmax
No change in Vmax

questions.text: Diamox is given to a patient with glaucoma. It is a non-competitive inhibitor of the carbonic anhydrase enzyme. Which of the following would be the effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Decrease in Vmax

 

Diamox (acetazolamide) is a non-competitive inhibitor of the enzyme carbonic anhydrase. The effects of a non-competitive inhibitor on enzyme kinetics are distinct:

 

  • Non-competitive Inhibition: This type of inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site other than the active site. This binding can occur whether or not the substrate has bound to the enzyme.
  • Vmax Decrease: The non-competitive inhibitor reduces the maximum rate of the reaction (Vmax) because it affects the enzyme's catalytic function. This means that even with a high substrate concentration, the enzyme cannot achieve the same Vmax as it would without the inhibitor.
  • Km Unchanged: The affinity of the enzyme for the substrate, represented by Km, remains unchanged because the inhibitor does not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. The substrate can still bind to the enzyme with the same affinity, but the enzyme-inhibitor complex cannot form the product at the same rate as the enzyme alone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease in Km: Explanation: This would be expected in the case of a competitive inhibitor, which increases the substrate concentration needed to achieve half of Vmax, effectively increasing Km. Non-competitive inhibition does not change Km.

 

Option C. Decrease in both Km and Vmax: Explanation: Non-competitive inhibitors do not affect Km because they do not interfere with substrate binding directly. They only reduce the catalytic activity, hence only Vmax is decreased.

 

Option D. No change in Vmax: Explanation: This is incorrect for non-competitive inhibitors, which specifically lower Vmax due to the reduced number of active enzyme molecules available for the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diamox, as a non-competitive inhibitor of carbonic anhydrase, decreases the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction without changing the Michaelis constant (Km). This inhibition reduces the enzyme's catalytic activity but does not alter its substrate binding affinity.

questions.text: Low apparent volume of distribution of drug indicates?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Not extensively distributed to tissues

 

Apparent Volume of distribution (Vd) = dose administered I.V/ plasma concentration It indicates how extensively the drug is distributed in the tissues. For example, Chloroquine has the highest volume of distribution, as it is mostly distributed to the liver and a very small amount is left for the action on RBC.

 

E.g.: If a 1000 mg of drug A is given i.v (100% bioavailability) and the plasma concentration reached is 10 mg/ liter then the apparent volume of distribution (Vd) is 1000/10= 10 liters.

 

But the normal blood volume is about 5 liters. A high Vd is due to accumulation of drug A being distributed in extravascular tissues resulting in low plasma concentration.

 

Half-life or t1/2 relationship with volume of distribution (Vd) and clearance (CI) is given by the formula t 1/2 = 0.693 × Vd /CI. t1/2 is directly proportional to Vd but it is also inversely proportional to clearance. If a drug has a low volume of distribution but clearance is very low, t1/2 can still be high. So low Vd doesn't always imply low t1/2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low t 1/2: The half-life (t1/2) of a drug is influenced by both its volume of distribution (Vd) and its clearance (Cl). It is given by the formula:

 

t1/2=0.693×Vd/Cl

 

A low Vd does not necessarily imply a low half-life, as the half-life is also dependent on the clearance of the drug. If the clearance is low, the half-life can still be long despite a low Vd.

 

Option B. Low bioavailability: Bioavailability refers to the fraction of an administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation in an unchanged form. It is primarily affected by the route of administration and first-pass metabolism, not by the volume of distribution.

 

Option C. Low efficacy: Efficacy refers to the ability of a drug to produce a desired therapeutic effect. It is determined by the drug’s mechanism of action and intrinsic activity at its target receptors, not by its volume of distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A low apparent volume of distribution (Vd) indicates that the drug is not extensively distributed to tissues and remains largely confined to the blood plasma. This parameter is essential for understanding the pharmacokinetic behavior of the drug in the body.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in heart failure?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trimetazidine

 

Trimetazidine is not used in heart failure because it is primarily a metabolic modulator. It partially inhibits the beta-oxidation of fatty acids, which results in shifting the metabolism of heart muscles from fatty acids to glucose. This shift requires less oxygen, making trimetazidine beneficial for patients with angina pectoris. However, it does not have a role in the management of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is used in the management of chronic heart failure. Beta-blockers are contraindicated in acute heart failure but can be beneficial in chronic heart failure when started at a low dose and gradually increased to avoid decompensation. The beta-blockers commonly used in heart failure include carvedilol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol.

 

Option C. Sacubitril: Sacubitril is an NEP (neutral endopeptidase) inhibitor, which prevents the breakdown of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP). By inhibiting NEP, sacubitril increases BNP levels, leading to natriuresis and vasodilation, which are beneficial effects in chronic heart failure (CHF). Therefore, sacubitril is used in the treatment of CHF.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a recombinant form of BNP and is administered through the subcutaneous route. It helps to induce natriuresis and vasodilation, thus can be used in the treatment of heart failure.

 

Educational objective:

 

Trimetazidine, although beneficial for angina pectoris due to its metabolic modulation properties, is not used in the treatment of heart failure.

 

Note - Beta blockers are contraindicated in acute heart failure, but they can be used in chronic heart failure. Beta blockers should be started at low dose, dose should be increased gradually to prevent decompensation.

 

Beta blockers used are – Carvedilol, metoprolol and bisoprolol.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 599, 600

choices.text: Cardiac defects
Facial defects
CNS defects

questions.text: Lithium usage in pregnancy can lead to which of the following teratogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cardiac defects

 

Lithium is a mood stabilizer commonly used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. However, its use during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of congenital cardiac defects, particularly Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Ebstein's Anomaly is a rare heart defect characterized by:

 

  • Malformation of the tricuspid valve
  • Downward displacement of the valve into the right ventricle
  • Abnormal development of the right ventricle leading to its partial arterialization

 

This condition results in a "box-shaped" heart appearance on radiographic imaging. Because of this risk, the use of lithium during pregnancy, especially during the first trimester, is generally avoided unless absolutely necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial defects: While certain medications and teratogens can cause facial defects, lithium is not primarily associated with facial anomalies. Drugs like isotretinoin are more commonly linked to facial defects.

 

Option C. CNS defects: CNS defects can be caused by various teratogens, but lithium is not specifically known to cause central nervous system malformations. Antiepileptic drugs like valproate have a higher association with CNS defects.

 

Option D. Urogenital defects: Lithium is not commonly associated with urogenital defects. These defects can be caused by other teratogens and genetic factors but are not linked to lithium usage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lithium is teratogenic in pregnancy as it can give rise to Ebstein’s anomaly. It is characterized by arterialization of the right ventricle, giving rise to a box-shaped heart when seen radiologically.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 drugs for 6 months

 

According to the latest WHO guidelines treatment of multibacillary and paucibacillary leprosy is same except for duration of treatment.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The treatment for paucibacillary leprosy involves a combination of three drugs (rifampin, clofazimine, and dapsone) administered over a period of 6 months.

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency with overdose some drug. There were increased salivation and increased bronchial secretions. On examination, blood pressure was 88/60 mmHg. RBC esterase level is 50. What should be the treatment of this person?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atropine

 

  • Low esterase levels are suggestive of overdose of some drug which acts by inhibiting acetyl choline esterase like organophosphate poisoning.
  • Inhibition of choline esterase results in increased amount of Ach at synapse, so poisoning or overdose results in cholinergic symptoms like salivation, lacrimation, urination, emesis, increased bronchial secretions, and reduction in blood pressure.
    So treatment of choice is Atropine.
  • Atropine - It is highly effective in counter-acting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects. It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action. All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly treated with atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear (upto 200 mg has been administered in a day). Continued treatment with maintenance doses may be required for 1-2 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is incorrect as it is an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor, which would worsen the cholinergic symptoms by increasing acetylcholine levels further.

 

Option C. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is incorrect because it is an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, not for organophosphate poisoning. It works by antagonizing the effects of benzodiazepines on the central nervous system.

 

Option D. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is incorrect as it is also an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor, which would exacerbate the symptoms of cholinergic overdose. Additionally, it is used to treat atropine poisoning, not organophosphate poisoning.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of organophosphate poisoning, which presents with cholinergic symptoms and low RBC esterase levels, the treatment of choice is atropine, administered intravenously until signs of atropinization appear.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/122

questions.text: All of the following can cause miosis except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Belladonna

 

Belladonna is plant (Atropa belladonna) from which atropine (Anticholinergic drug) is obtained. It causes mydriasis not miosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphates: Organophosphates cause miosis by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, which increases acetylcholine levels, resulting in overstimulation of muscarinic receptors.

 

Option C. Morphine: Morphine induces miosis by stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system through opioid receptors, leading to pupil constriction.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug that causes miosis by directly activating muscarinic receptors in the eye.

 

Educational objective:

 

Miosis or pin point pupil is caused by:-

 

  • Organophosphate poisoning
  • Opioids like morphine
  • Phenol poisoning
  • Pontine hemorrhage
  • Cholinergic drugs like pilocarpine

 

Reference: KDT 8th/115,122,127,499

choices.text: To allay anxiety
To decrease secretions
For muscle relaxation

questions.text: A patient was schedule for surgery. Before giving anaesthesia, he was administered glycopyrrolate. What is rationale of giving glycopyrrolate before anaesthesia?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. To decrease secretions

 

  • Preanesthetic medication refers to the use of drugs before anaesthesia to make it safe and less unpleasant.
  • When inhalation anaesthetic agents are given, they inhibit the ciliary function resulting in accumulation of secretions in the respiratory pathway. Therefore anti-cholinergic drugs like atropine or glycopyrrolate are used as pre-anaesthetic medication for their anti-secretory action.
  • Glycopyrrolate is twice as potent and longer acting quaternary anti-muscarinic which does not produce central effects. Anti-secretory action is more marked than atropine and tachycardia is less marked. It acts rapidly when given i.v. and is the preferred anti-muscarinic in anaesthetic practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To allay anxiety: Glycopyrrolate is not used to allay anxiety. Anxiolytics such as benzodiazepines are typically used for this purpose.

 

Option C. As inducing agent: Glycopyrrolate is not an inducing agent. Inducing agents are drugs like propofol or thiopental used to induce anaesthesia.

 

Option D. For muscle relaxation: Glycopyrrolate is not used for muscle relaxation. Muscle relaxants like vecuronium or succinylcholine are used for this purpose during surgical procedures.

 

Educational objective:

 

Glycopyrrolate is administered before anaesthesia to decrease respiratory secretions, making the anaesthetic procedure safer and more efficient by preventing the accumulation of secretions that can interfere with the airway during surgery.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 413,414

questions.text: An infant of 2 months had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which of the following drugs during the third trimester for this to occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Co-trimoxazole

 

Co-trimoxazole is a combination of two antibiotics: trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole. Sulfamethoxazole is a sulfonamide, which can displace bilirubin from its binding sites on plasma albumin. This displacement increases the free bilirubin levels in the blood, which can cross the blood-brain barrier and potentially lead to kernicterus, a type of brain damage resulting from very high levels of bilirubin in a newborn's blood.

 

When pregnant women take sulfonamides near term, these drugs can cross the placenta and affect the fetus, increasing the risk of hyperbilirubinemia and kernicterus in newborns. Therefore, Co-trimoxazole is contraindicated during the third trimester of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ampicillin: Ampicillin is a penicillin antibiotic. It does not displace bilirubin from albumin, and therefore, it is not associated with an increased risk of hyperbilirubinemia or kernicterus in newborns.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic. It is not known to displace bilirubin from albumin and is not associated with an increased risk of hyperbilirubinemia or kernicterus in newborns.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol: Chloramphenicol is an antibiotic that can cause gray baby syndrome when given to newborns due to their immature liver enzymes, but it does not typically cause hyperbilirubinemia or kernicterus. It is not known to displace bilirubin from albumin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Co-trimoxazole, which contains the sulfonamide sulfamethoxazole, can displace bilirubin from plasma albumin, increasing the risk of hyperbilirubinemia and kernicterus in newborns. Therefore, it is contraindicated during the third trimester of pregnancy or during lactation.

questions.text: Which of the following anti rheumatoid drug increases extracellular adenosine? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

 

Methotrexate works primarily by inhibiting AICAR transformylase and thymidylate synthetase.

 

AICAR accumulates intracellularly and competes with AMP deaminase, resulting in AMP accumulation. AMP is released and converted extracellularly to adenosine, which is acts as the powerful anti-inflammatory agent. As a result, neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, and lymphocytes' inflammatory functions are suppressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leflunomide: Leflunomide inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, which is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidines, thereby suppressing the proliferation of activated lymphocytes. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option C. Sulphasalazine: Sulphasalazine is a prodrug that is metabolized into sulfapyridine and 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA). Its anti-inflammatory effects are primarily due to the action of 5-ASA. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: Hydroxychloroquine is thought to exert its anti-inflammatory effects by interfering with lysosomal activity and autophagy in immune cells, and by modulating the activity of toll-like receptors (TLRs). It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate increases extracellular adenosine by inhibiting AICAR transformylase, leading to the accumulation of AICAR, which competes with AMP deaminase and causes AMP to accumulate and be converted to adenosine outside the cell, thus exerting anti-inflammatory effects.

choices.text: Unfractionated Heparin
Low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: Which is the anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Low molecular weight heparin

 

LMWH is the anticoagulant of choice for the treatment of Cancer associated thromboembolism. It has a long half-life, higher bioavailability and does not require anticoagulant monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unfractionated Heparin: While effective, it requires continuous intravenous infusion and frequent monitoring of activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), making it less convenient for long-term management.

 

Option B. Warfarin: Warfarin requires regular monitoring of the international normalized ratio (INR) to maintain therapeutic levels, which can be challenging in cancer patients due to potential drug interactions and varying dietary intake.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor. Although effective, it is not the first choice for cancer-associated thromboembolism due to limited evidence compared to LMWH and potential for drug interactions and gastrointestinal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for managing cancer-associated thromboembolism due to its long half-life, higher bioavailability, and the convenience of not requiring routine anticoagulant monitoring.

questions.text: Which of the following new drugs has been approved for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Edaravone

 

Edaravone is an FDA approved drug used in the treatment of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

 

It has free radical scavenging properties that may reduce oxidative stress although the exact mechanism of action is unknown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Piracetam: Piracetam is used off-label for cognitive enhancement and the treatment of myoclonus. It is not approved for the treatment of ALS.

 

Option C. Dabrafenib: Dabrafenib is a targeted therapy used for the treatment of BRAF V600E mutation-positive melanoma. It is not used for ALS.

 

Option D. Trametinib: Trametinib is also used for the treatment of BRAF V600E mutation-positive melanoma. It is not indicated for ALS.

 

Educational Objective

 

Edaravone is the new drug approved for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), primarily due to its free radical scavenging properties that may help reduce oxidative stress, a factor involved in the disease's progression.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Azithromycin, doxycycline

 

The DOC for scrub typhus is Doxycycline, but it cannot be used during pregnancy as it can lead to bone growth abnormality in the newborn. So, in that case, to treat Scrub Typhus in Pregnancy, we use Azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloramphenicol, doxycycline: Chloramphenicol is not the first-line treatment for scrub typhus, and doxycycline is indeed used for non-pregnant individuals, but this pair does not cover the correct alternatives during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Doxycycline, doxycycline: This option does not address the contraindication of doxycycline during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Doxycycline, azithromycin: This reverses the correct pair; azithromycin is used during pregnancy, not doxycycline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for treating scrub typhus in pregnant women is azithromycin, while doxycycline is used for non-pregnant individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a GPCR? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Muscarinic

 

Muscarinic receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors. Out of them, M1 and M3 act through Gq pathway and via the IP3/DAG pathway, whereas M2 and M4 act via Gi protein, that inhibits adenylyl cyclase leading to a decrease in the levels of cAMP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nicotinic: Nicotinic receptors are ionotropic receptors, which means they are ion channel receptors and not GPCRs. They allow the passage of ions across the cell membrane when activated.

 

Option C. GABA-A: GABA-A receptors are also ionotropic receptors that function as chloride ion channels. They are not GPCRs.

 

Option D. Insulin: The insulin receptor is a receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK), not a GPCR. It initiates a cascade of intracellular signaling upon binding insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscarinic receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) that play a role in various physiological processes through different G-protein signaling pathways.

choices.text: Spurious drug
Adulterated drug
Unethical drug

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

 

A drug stating that 500mg of paracetamol is present in each tablet, but contains only 200mg is a misbranded drug.

 

A misbranded drug will not produce the effect due to reasons like lesser dose, different molecules in it etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious drugs: are drugs with improper labelling, labeling from a fictitious company, with improper storage guidelines, or even partly or wholly substituted by another drug or substance.

 

Option B. Adulterated drugs: are drugs with unwanted substance, for example iron in Paracetamol.

 

Option C. unethical drug: The term unethical drug is not used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A drug that is labeled as containing a certain amount of an active ingredient but actually contains a different amount is considered misbranded. Misbranded drugs can lead to ineffective treatment and potential harm due to incorrect dosing.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metoclopramide

 

Metoclopramide is an anti-emetic that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can cross the blood brain barrier and can lead to Dopaminergic blockade in the various parts of the brain leading to Acute dystonia, drowsiness, abnormal posturing, Parkinsonism etc.

 

Domperidone is also a D2 Receptor blocker, but cannot cross the BBB, therefore it does not produce such side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that does not typically cause extrapyramidal side effects. It is used to reduce salivation and bronchial secretions and to treat bradycardia.

 

Option B. Ranitidine: Ranitidine is an H2 receptor antagonist used to reduce stomach acid production. It does not have significant central nervous system effects or cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Domperidone: Domperidone is also a dopamine D2 receptor blocker used as an anti-emetic. However, it does not cross the blood-brain barrier effectively and therefore does not typically cause central nervous system side effects like metoclopramide.

 

Educational Objective

 

Metoclopramide, an anti-emetic that blocks D2 receptors and crosses the blood-brain barrier, can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as acute dystonia, drowsiness, abnormal posturing, and Parkinsonism-like symptoms.

choices.text: Ketoconazole: Lanosterol-14-demethylase inhibition
Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis
Terbinafine: Squalene epoxidase inhibition
Amphotericin B: Sequesters ergosterol

questions.text: Identify the wrongly matched pair of antifungals with its mechanism of action? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis

 

All of the above Antifungal agents are correctly matched with their corresponding mechanisms of action except for Flucytosine. Flucytosine acts by inhibiting the synthesis of nucleic acid. Griseofulvin is the antifungal that acts by inhibiting microtubule synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Lanosterol-14-demethylase inhibition

Ketoconazole is correctly matched. It inhibits lanosterol-14-demethylase, an enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of ergosterol, which is a crucial component of the fungal cell membrane.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Squalene epoxidase inhibition

Terbinafine is correctly matched. It inhibits squalene epoxidase, an enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of ergosterol, leading to the accumulation of toxic levels of squalene and cell death.

 

Option D. Amphotericin B: Sequesters ergosterol

Amphotericin B is correctly matched. It binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that increase membrane permeability and cause cell contents to leak out, leading to cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flucytosine inhibits nucleic acid synthesis, not microtubule synthesis. The correct antifungal that inhibits microtubule synthesis is griseofulvin.

choices.text: Area under the curve

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is used to assess the extent of drug absorption in a plasma concentration vs. time graph? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Area under the curve

 

In the Concentration-time curve for a given drug, the area under the curve (AUC) tells us about the bioavailability of the drug.

 

The bioavailability of a given drug is defined as the fraction of the given dose that reaches the systemic circulation.

 

It depends on 2 factors:

 

1.Absorption of the drug (More the extent of absorption of the drug, greater is the bioavailability)

 

2.First pass metabolism of the drug (More the first pass metabolism of a drug, lesser is its bioavailability).

 

So, in other words, the AUC tells us about the extent of absorption of the drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tmax: The time to reach the maximum concentration (Cmax) in plasma. It indicates the rate of absorption but not the extent of absorption.

 

Option B. Cmax: The maximum concentration of the drug in plasma. It provides information on the peak level achieved but does not reflect the overall extent of absorption.

 

Option C. T1/2: The half-life of the drug, which is the time it takes for the plasma concentration to reduce by half. This parameter is related to the duration of action and elimination of the drug, not the extent of absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Area Under the Curve (AUC) in a plasma concentration vs. time graph is used to assess the extent of drug absorption, reflecting the bioavailability of the drug in the systemic circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following routes of administration will not bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral

 

Hepatic first-pass metabolism refers to the process where the concentration of a drug is greatly reduced before it reaches the systemic circulation. This occurs primarily when drugs are metabolized in the liver after being absorbed.

 

When a drug is taken orally, it is absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract and then passes through the liver before reaching systemic circulation. This route is subject to significant hepatic first-pass metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sublingual: This route involves placing a drug under the tongue, where it is absorbed directly into the bloodstream through the tissues beneath the tongue. It bypasses the liver initially, thus avoiding hepatic first-pass metabolism.

 

Option C. Intravenous (IV): Intravenous administration delivers a drug directly into the bloodstream, completely bypassing the liver initially. Therefore, it does not undergo first-pass metabolism.

 

Option D. Transdermal: Transdermal administration involves applying a drug through the skin (e.g., via a patch). The drug is absorbed directly into systemic circulation, bypassing the liver initially and thus avoiding first-pass metabolism.

 

Note: Please read the question carefully, which does not bypass means which undergoes first pass metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The route of administration that does not bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism is Oral. This is because drugs taken orally are absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and then pass through the liver where they may be metabolically altered before reaching the systemic circulation.

questions.text: For the action of heparin as an anticoagulant, availability of which of the following chemical substances is mandatory? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Antithrombin-III

 

Heparin acts indirectly by activating Antithrombin-III. The heparin-antithrombin III then binds to the clotting factors of the intrinsic pathway (10, 2, 9 ,11 and 12) and inactivates them. The anticoagulation action is exerted mainly by the inhibition of factor 10 as well as thrombin or factor 2. Therefore Antithrombin-Ill is mandatory for the action of heparin as an anticoagulant. Reduced antithrombin levels can lead to resistance.

 

In true heparin resistance, there is an actual blunting of heparin's anticoagulant effect. This occurs due to:

 

  • Low ATIII levels (most common cause)
  • Increased heparin-binding plasma proteins (acute phase reactants)
  • Increased heparin clearance (e.g., due to splenomegaly in liver disease)

 

Low ATIII levels could be due to decreased synthesis (hereditary, hepatic failure), increased consumption (DIC, MAHA, or in a bypass circuit) or increased loss (nephrotic syndrome).

 

The dose of heparin has to be increased to achieve therapeutic aPTT. Severe antithrombin deficiency may require antithrombin concentrate as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thrombin: Thrombin is a target of the heparin-antithrombin III complex, not a necessary cofactor for heparin's action.

 

Option B. Plasmin: Plasmin is involved in fibrinolysis (the breakdown of clots) and is not directly related to the anticoagulant action of heparin.

 

Option D. Thrombomodulin: Thrombomodulin is a receptor that binds thrombin and is involved in the activation of protein C, which has anticoagulant properties. However, it is not directly required for the action of heparin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The availability of antithrombin-III is mandatory for the anticoagulant action of heparin, as it forms a complex with heparin to inactivate key enzymes in the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: What is the bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 100%
