Bioavailability of an administered drug is the fraction of that drug that reaches unchanged into systemic circulation. It depends upon 2 factors:

 

  • Absorption of the drug from the site of application
  • First pass metabolism

 

The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously (I.V) is 100% because it is neither subjected to the first-pass metabolism as in oral route nor does it depend on local factors that affect absorption as in subcutaneous, intramuscular, or transdermal. In IV route, the drug is directly delivered to the systemic circulation and hence has the maximum availability for action at the intended site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously is 100% because the drug is directly delivered into the systemic circulation without any loss due to absorption barriers or first-pass metabolism.

questions.text: A drug solution containing 500 mg/5 ml of the drug is given to you. You are provided with a 2 ml syringe (having 10 divisions for each mI). How many divisions of the 2 m syringe need to be administered to deliver 180 mg of the drug to a patient? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 18

 

500 mg of the drug is present in 5ml of the solution.

 

Therefore, 180 mg will be present in (5/500) *180 = 1.8ml

 

In the syringe provided, 1ml = 10 divisions,

 

Therefore 1.8ml = 18 divisions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To deliver 180 mg of the drug using the provided 2 ml syringe with 10 divisions per ml, you need to fill the syringe to 18 divisions.

choices.text: Monitoring of lithium therapy
Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy
Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics
Administration of nicotine patches

questions.text: Z track technique is used for (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics

 

Z track technique is a technique used for intramuscular injection.


During Z track technique, skin is stretched to one side before injecting the needle so that the point of injection and point of deposition of drug are not in straight line. This decreases the risk of efflux back of drug.

 

Advantages of Z track technique –

 

  • It will not cause any pigmentation
  • Lithium and carbamazepine are oral drugs and monitoring is done by taking blood through intravenous route.
  • Long acting depot antipsychotics are given by intramuscular route via z-track technique.
  • Nicotine patches are applied on the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitoring of lithium therapy: Lithium therapy is monitored through blood tests, not intramuscular injections. Blood samples are taken intravenously to measure lithium levels.

 

Option B. Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy: Carbamazepine therapy is also monitored through blood tests. Blood samples are taken intravenously to measure carbamazepine levels, and the medication is usually taken orally.

 

Option D. Administration of nicotine patches: Nicotine patches are applied transdermally to the skin. The Z track technique is not relevant for this method of administration.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Z track technique is used for intramuscular injections, particularly for long-acting depot antipsychotics, to ensure proper deposition of the medication and prevent leakage back through the injection path.

choices.text: Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation
Reduced cardiac contractility
Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume
Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure

questions.text: A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation

 

Nitrates cause endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation when treating Prinzmetal angina.

 

Coronary artery vasospasm is the underlying cause of Prinzmetal angina. By relaxing the smooth muscles of the epicardial coronary arteries, nitrates treat coronary artery spasm.

 

The main mechanism of action of nitrates in the event of stable angina is preferred vein dilation (by increasing cGMP). Venous return to the heart is reduced as a result of venous dilatation (preload). Due to the reduction in ventricular end-diastolic volume, myocardial oxygen consumption also reduces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduced cardiac contractility: This is not the primary mechanism of action of nitrates in relieving Prinzmetal angina. Nitrates primarily work by vasodilation rather than affecting myocardial contractility.

 

Option C. Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume: Nitrates generally reduce the preload (venous return) by dilating veins, which can lead to a decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic volume, not an increase.

 

Option D. Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure: While nitrates can lower blood pressure, the primary therapeutic effect in Prinzmetal angina is not related to diastolic perfusion pressure but to the direct vasodilation of the coronary arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitrates provide symptomatic relief in Prinzmetal angina through endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation, which helps to alleviate coronary artery spasms and restore proper blood flow to the heart muscle.

questions.text: In a middle-aged diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease stage 5, which of the following drugs can be given safely without altering the dose? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Linagliptin

 

The gliptins are DPP4 inhibitors used in the management of type 2 DM. They are eliminated through the kidneys and are therefore contraindicated in patients with CKD. Only Linagliptin can be safely administered in such cases, as it is eliminated through the hepatobiliary system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vildagliptin: Vildagliptin is excreted primarily through the kidneys. In patients with severe renal impairment (CKD stage 5), dose adjustments are necessary to avoid drug accumulation and toxicity.

 

Option C. Saxagliptin: Saxagliptin also undergoes significant renal excretion. Therefore, it requires dose adjustments in patients with severe renal impairment to ensure safe and effective use.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: Similar to vildagliptin and saxagliptin, sitagliptin is primarily excreted by the kidneys. Dose adjustments are necessary in patients with advanced CKD to avoid the risk of adverse effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin can be safely administered to patients with chronic kidney disease stage 5 without the need for dose adjustments due to its unique hepatobiliary excretion pathway, making it the preferred DPP-4 inhibitor in such cases.

choices.text: Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM
Adrenaline 1 mg 1/10000 IV
Atropine 3 mg
Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV

questions.text: The drug of choice in Anaphylactic Shock is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM

 

Anaphylactic shock is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that requires immediate treatment. The first-line treatment for anaphylactic shock is the administration of adrenaline (epinephrine). Adrenaline works by counteracting the severe hypotension, bronchospasm, and edema that occur during anaphylactic reactions.

 

Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM is the recommended dose for the treatment of anaphylaxis. This intramuscular injection provides rapid absorption and action, which is critical in managing the symptoms of anaphylaxis effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adrenaline 1 mg 1/10000 IV: This dose and concentration of adrenaline are typically used in cardiac arrest scenarios, not for initial treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Option C. Atropine 3 mg: Atropine is used primarily to treat bradycardia (slow heart rate) and is not effective in managing anaphylactic shock.

 

Option D. Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV: Adenosine is used to treat certain types of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and is not relevant for the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: No advice as most of drug are not present in breast milk
Give longer half-life drugs
Tell the mother to feed when it is least efficacious
To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

questions.text: What advice do you give to a mother who is using medications during lactation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

 

When administering medications to a lactating mother, the timing of breast feeding is very important. It is advised to feed the baby just before the intake of the drug, as at that time the plasma concentration of the drug would be least. Then after feeding the drug is taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No advice as most of the drug are not present in breast milk: This is incorrect. Many drugs can pass into breast milk to varying degrees. Therefore, careful consideration and advice are needed to minimize infant exposure.

 

Option B. Give longer half-life drugs: This is not a general recommendation. Drugs with longer half-lives stay in the body longer and can potentially accumulate in the breast milk, increasing exposure to the infant.

 

Option C. Tell the mother to feed when it is least efficacious: This advice is not clear or practical. The key is to time breastfeeding relative to the dosing schedule to minimize drug transfer to the breast milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best advice for a lactating mother using medications is to breastfeed just before taking her next dose of medication. This practice ensures that the drug's plasma concentration is at its lowest during breastfeeding, thereby reducing the amount of drug that passes into the breast milk and minimizing exposure to the infant.

choices.text: Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
Corticosteroids cause direct bronchodilatation when used with xanthine
Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthine on adenosine receptor
Corticosteroids increase mucous secretion.

questions.text: Acute exacerbation of asthma was comprehended, salbutamol was prescribed, however, no improvement was noticed. Intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were given and the condition improved. What is the probable mechanism by which the corticosteroids would have improved the condition? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol

 

Corticosteroids are not bronchodilators by itself, but they are used in acute exacerbation of asthma because they decrease the secretion of mucous, decrease the inflammatory mediators and also increase the responsiveness of the β receptors to the action of the β2 agonists. Therefore, it can be said that Corticosteroids improved the condition by increasing the airway responsiveness to salbutamol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticosteroids cause direct bronchodilatation when used with xanthine: This is incorrect. Corticosteroids do not cause direct bronchodilation. Their primary role is to reduce inflammation and enhance the effects of bronchodilators.

 

Option C. Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthine on adenosine receptor: This is incorrect. Corticosteroids do not have a direct or indirect effect on the xanthine (aminophylline) action on adenosine receptors.

 

Option D. Corticosteroids increase mucous secretion: This is incorrect. Corticosteroids actually decrease mucus secretion, which helps to clear the airways and improve airflow during an asthma exacerbation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids improve the condition of patients with acute asthma exacerbation by increasing the bronchial responsiveness to β2 agonists like salbutamol, reducing inflammation, and decreasing mucus secretion.

choices.text: Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure free interval is needed
Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic
Discontinue the drug as he is seizure free

questions.text: An epileptic patient on levetiracetam has been seizure-free for 2 years. But he develops agitation and anger issues interfering with his day-to-day activities as a result of the drug intake. Which of the following measures is to be taken next? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months

 

Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic drug that binds to SV2A on the vesicles and modulates the release of Neurotransmitters. It can cause anger, agitation and mood disturbances as a side effect. In such cases, the drug should be gradually tapered over the next 6 months, but not abruptly stopped as that might lead to rebound seizures.

 

Rationale for Tapering:

 

  • Side Effects: The patient is experiencing significant side effects (agitation and anger) that are interfering with daily activities.
  • Seizure-Free Period: While the patient has been seizure-free for 2 years, abruptly stopping the medication could lead to rebound seizures.
  • Gradual Tapering: Tapering the medication slowly over the next 6 months is a safer approach. It allows the patient's body to adjust and reduces the risk of withdrawal seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure-free interval is needed: While a longer seizure-free interval might be ideal, continuing the medication despite significant side effects is not practical. The patient’s quality of life is important, and the side effects need to be addressed.

 

Option C. Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic: Abruptly stopping levetiracetam is not recommended due to the risk of withdrawal seizures. Switching to a different antiepileptic drug (AED) should be done cautiously, and often a cross-tapering strategy is used.

 

Option D. Discontinue the drug as he is seizure-free: Discontinuing the drug abruptly is not advisable, even if the patient has been seizure-free, because it could trigger rebound seizures. A gradual tapering is always preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient on levetiracetam experiences significant psychiatric side effects, the best approach is to slowly taper the medication over several months to prevent rebound seizures and address the side effects.

questions.text:
A drug was given IV at a rate of 1.6 mg/min. The clearance of the drug is 640 ml/min.

The half-life of the drug is 1.8 hour. Calculate the plasma concentration of the drug?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 0.002mg/ml

 

Plasma conc of a drug (C) = Amount of drug being eliminated/Clearance

 

When the amount of drug administered equals the amount of drug eliminated from the body, steady-state plasma concentration is reached.

 

The amount of drug being administered = 1.6 mg/min

 

Clearance = 640ml/min

 

Therefore,

 

Plasma concentration of the drug = 1.6 mg/min / 640 ml/min = 0.0025 mg/ml.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When given the rate of infusion and clearance, the steady-state plasma concentration of a drug can be calculated using the formula:

 

Plasma concentration (C)=Rate of infusion (R)/ Clearance (Cl)

questions.text: Which of the following opioids is an antagonist at ‘µ’ and a complete agonist at ‘k’ receptors? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pentazocine

 

Pentazocine is an opioid agonist-antagonist agent, which acts as a full agonist at the Kappa receptors but as a partial agonist or antagonist at the mu receptors. It is used as an analgesic, but contraindicated in myocardial infarction due to its potential to increase heart rate and blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at mu (μ) receptors and an antagonist at kappa (κ) receptors. It is used for pain management and in the treatment of opioid dependence.

 

Option C. Tramadol: Tramadol is a weak agonist at mu (μ) receptors and also inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. It does not have significant kappa (κ) receptor activity.

 

Option D. Fentanyl: Fentanyl is a potent full agonist at mu (μ) receptors with no significant activity at kappa (κ) receptors. It is used for severe pain management, particularly in surgical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pentazocine is an opioid that acts as an antagonist at mu (μ) receptors and a full agonist at kappa (κ) receptors. This unique profile allows it to serve as an analgesic with a potentially lower risk of certain side effects, although it is contraindicated in myocardial infarction.

choices.text: 70% amorphous 30% crystalline
70% crystalline 30% amorphous
Only 70% amorphous
D Other name of NPH insulin

questions.text: Composition of Lente insulin is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 70% crystalline 30% amorphous

 

Lente insulin has two components in it:

 

  • Ultralente insulin, which is water insoluble insulin zinc suspension with large crystalline particles (70%), it has a long half-life.
  • Semilente insulin, which is amorphous, has smaller particles and is short acting. (30%)
  • These two components are mixed in this 7:3 ratio, making Lente insulin intermediate acting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70% amorphous 30% crystalline: This is incorrect as the amorphous part makes up only 30% of the composition in Lente insulin.

 

Option C. Only 70% amorphous: This is incorrect because Lente insulin is a mixture of both crystalline and amorphous components, not just one type.

 

Option D. Other name of NPH insulin: This is incorrect. Lente insulin and NPH (Neutral Protamine Hagedorn) insulin are different formulations. NPH insulin is an intermediate-acting insulin that is a suspension of insulin with protamine and zinc, which prolongs its action, but it is not referred to as Lente insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lente insulin is composed of 70% crystalline (long-acting) and 30% amorphous (short-acting) insulin, making it an intermediate-acting insulin formulation.

choices.text: Inhibition of M2 receptor
Neuraminidase inhibition
Inhibition of RNA dependent DNA polymerase
Apoptosis of infected cells

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Oseltamivir as an antiviral agent is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Neuraminidase inhibition

 

Oseltamivir, commonly known by its brand name Tamiflu, is an antiviral medication primarily used to treat and prevent Influenza A and B. Its mechanism of action is as follows:

 

  • Neuraminidase inhibition: Oseltamivir works by inhibiting the viral enzyme neuraminidase. Neuraminidase is crucial for the viral life cycle because it cleaves sialic acid residues on the surface of host cells and on viral proteins, which facilitates the release of new viral particles from infected cells. By inhibiting neuraminidase, Oseltamivir prevents the release and spread of the virus, thus limiting the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of M2 receptor: This is incorrect. The M2 receptor is targeted by another antiviral drug, Amantadine, which is used against influenza A by inhibiting viral uncoating.

 

Option C. Inhibition of RNA dependent DNA polymerase: This is incorrect. Inhibition of RNA-dependent DNA polymerase is the mechanism of action for antiretroviral drugs like reverse transcriptase inhibitors used in HIV treatment.

 

Option D. Apoptosis of infected cells: This is incorrect. Inducing apoptosis of infected cells is not the mechanism by which Oseltamivir works. It primarily prevents the release of new viral particles rather than directly inducing cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor that is used to treat Influenza A and B. Inhibition of viral neuraminidase inhibits the release of viral progeny from the infected host cells.

questions.text: The drug of choice for insomnia in blind people is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tasimelteon

 

Tasimelteon and Ramelteon are melatonin agonists. Tasimelteon is used for the treatment of insomnia in blind persons, whereas Ramelteon is used for the treatment of jet lag and also used for sleep induction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Latanoprostene: Is not relevant to the treatment of insomnia. It is a medication used to reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma or ocular hypertension.

 

Option B. Zerviate: Is an antihistamine eye drop used for the treatment of ocular itching associated with allergic conjunctivitis, not for insomnia.

 

Option D. Ramelteon: Is also a melatonin receptor agonist used for the treatment of insomnia, specifically for difficulties with sleep onset. It is not specifically indicated for Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder in blind individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tasimelteon is the drug of choice for treating insomnia in blind individuals due to its effectiveness in regulating the sleep-wake cycle by acting as a melatonin receptor agonist, particularly in those with Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder.

questions.text: A male patient with a psychotic disorder is receiving antipsychotic, antidepressant, and antihypertensive medication. He developed tachycardia and chest tightness all of a sudden. He was diagnosed with metabolic acidosis. The ECG revealed a widened QRS complex and a prolonged QT interval. Which of the following drugs is the cause of this? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amitriptyline

 

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). TCAs are known for their potential to cause significant cardiac toxicity, particularly in overdose situations. The mechanism includes:

 

  • Cardiac Sodium Channel Blockade: This leads to a widened QRS complex on the ECG.
  • Prolongation of QT Interval: TCAs can also block potassium channels, leading to a prolonged QT interval and potentially resulting in Torsades de pointes, a life-threatening arrhythmia.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: TCAs can cause metabolic acidosis due to their effects on the central nervous system and cardiovascular system, which can result in decreased perfusion and tissue hypoxia.

 

Management: In cases of TCA overdose, the treatment of choice is intravenous sodium bicarbonate, which helps to narrow the QRS complex and stabilize the cardiac membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension and angina. It does not typically cause a widened QRS complex or a prolonged QT interval and is not associated with metabolic acidosis in overdose situations.

 

Option C. Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic used for hypertension. It is not associated with the cardiac effects described (widened QRS, prolonged QT) or metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Enalapril: Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor used for hypertension and heart failure. It does not typically cause a widened QRS complex or prolonged QT interval and is not associated with metabolic acidosis in overdose situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amitriptyline is a TCA which can lead to widened QRS complex in the ECG along with prolonged QT interval-leading to Torsades de pointes. The antidote used in Amitriptyline toxicity is Sodium Bicarbonate.

choices.text: Ranitidine tablet before start of trip
Dimenhydrinate before start of trip
Scopolamine patch the night before trip
Omeprazole the night before and before starts of trip

questions.text: You and your friend plan for a mountain trip for the day after. What medication would you advise him to help with his motion sickness? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Scopolamine patch the night before trip

 

Scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug that is highly effective for the prevention and treatment of motion sickness. It works by blocking the muscarinic receptors in the central nervous system, which helps prevent the nausea and vomiting associated with motion sickness.

 

  • Transdermal Scopolamine Patch: The patch is typically applied behind the ear at least 4-5 hours before the trip and can provide continuous relief for up to 72 hours. This makes it highly convenient for trips that may last for several days

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ranitidine tablet before start of trip: Ranitidine is a histamine-2 receptor antagonist used to reduce stomach acid production. It is not effective for the prevention of motion sickness.

 

Option B. Dimenhydrinate before start of trip: Dimenhydrinate (Dramamine) is an antihistamine that can be effective for treating motion sickness, but it requires more frequent dosing compared to the scopolamine patch. It is taken orally and must be dosed every 4-6 hours.

 

Option D. Omeprazole the night before and before start of trip: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor used to reduce stomach acid production and treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is not effective for preventing motion sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scopolamine, particularly in the form of a transdermal patch, is the drug of choice for the prevention of motion sickness. The patch should be applied the night before the trip to ensure it is effective in preventing the symptoms of motion sickness. Ranitidine and Omeprazole are not effective. Dimenhydrinate is an anti-histaminic drug which is not as effective as scopolamine.

choices.text: Class I
Class II
Class III

questions.text: Dofetilide belongs to which class of anti-arrhythmic drugs? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Class III

 

Dofetilide is a class III anti arrhythmic drug that works by blocking K+ channels. The other class III anti arrhythmic include Amiodarone, Ibutilide, Sotalol and bretylium.

 

The side effect is QT prolongation/Torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I: These are sodium channel blockers.

 

Option B. Class II: These are beta-blockers.

 

Option D. Class IV: These are calcium channel blockers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class III drugs include:

B: Bretylium

I: Ibutilide

N

D: Dofetilide

A: Amiodarone

S: Sotalol

choices.text: Cell wall synthesis inhibition
Cell membrane inhibition
Peptide synthesis inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of vancomycin? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cell wall synthesis inhibition

 

Vancomycin binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase.

 

Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent used against gram positive agent like MRSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell membrane inhibition: This is not the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Drugs like polymyxins target the cell membrane.

 

Option C. Peptide synthesis inhibition: This option is incorrect. Peptide synthesis inhibition is typically the mechanism of action for drugs like tetracyclines and macrolides that interfere with ribosomal function.

 

Option D. 50S ribosome inhibition: This is not the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Drugs like macrolides (e.g., erythromycin), chloramphenicol, and clindamycin inhibit the 50S ribosomal subunit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, preventing peptidoglycan elongation and cross-linking, leading to cell lysis and death. It is especially effective against gram-positive bacteria like MRSA.

choices.text: Excretion in saliva
Excretion in urine
Large volume of distribution
Small volume of distribution

questions.text: Which of the following suggests storage of drugs in tissue (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Large volume of distribution

 

Large volume of distribution suggests storage of drugs in tissue. The volume of distribution (Vd) is a pharmacokinetic parameter that reflects the extent of drug distribution throughout the body. A large Vd indicates that a drug is extensively distributed throughout the tissues, including organs and fluids. This suggests that the drug is likely to be stored in the tissues and may have a long half-life. In contrast, a small Vd indicates that the drug is primarily confined to the bloodstream and has limited distribution to the tissues. Excretion in saliva or urine does not necessarily suggest storage of drugs in tissues, and the volume of distribution is not directly related to excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excretion in saliva: Excretion in saliva does not provide direct information about the extent of drug distribution or storage in tissues. It is more related to the route of elimination.

 

Option B. Excretion in urine: Excretion in urine indicates renal elimination of the drug or its metabolites. It provides information about the drug's elimination route but not about its distribution or storage in tissues.

 

Option D. Small volume of distribution: A small Vd indicates that the drug is largely confined to the bloodstream and has limited distribution to the tissues. This means the drug is not significantly stored in the tissues and is more likely to be readily available in the blood for excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A large volume of distribution (Vd) suggests that a drug is extensively distributed and stored in the body's tissues, which can result in a prolonged half-life and slower elimination from the body.

questions.text: The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug 'X'. What would be the probable mechanism of action of drug 'X'? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. β1 agonist and β2 agonist

 

The drug's likely mechanism of action is β1 and β2 agonism.

 

Due to its action on β1 receptors, there is an increase in the HR of the patient and also of the SBP (Increase in HR leads to an increase in the CO upto a certain extent). The agonistic action on the β2 receptors causes vasodilation and leads to a fall in the DBP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. α1 agonist and β1 agonist: α1 agonists typically cause vasoconstriction, which would increase both SBP and DBP. This does not align with the observed decrease in DBP.

 

Option B. M2 agonist and M3 agonist: M2 and M3 receptor agonism would likely lead to bradycardia and increased gastrointestinal motility, respectively. They do not explain the observed increase in HR and SBP, nor the decrease in DBP.

 

Option C. α1 antagonist and β2 agonist: While α1 antagonism could contribute to a decrease in DBP through vasodilation, it would not typically cause an increase in SBP and HR, which are more specifically associated with β1 agonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of increased systolic blood pressure, decreased diastolic blood pressure, and increased heart rate suggests that drug 'X' acts as a β1 and β2 agonist, leading to increased cardiac output and vasodilation.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia presented to the hospital, his BP is 88/68 mm Hg, Serum K+ is 6 mEq/L, serum sodium is 120 mEq/L. Patient was started on intravenous fluids. What additional specific therapy will you add?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydrocortisone

 

The presentation of an 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension (BP is 88/68 mm Hg, which is low for this age), hyperkalemia (serum K of 6 mEq/L), and hyponatremia (serum sodium of 120 mEq/L) is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most likely due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This is a common form of CAH and can lead to a decrease in cortisol and aldosterone production, with an accompanying increase in adrenal androgens.

 

Given this clinical picture, the specific therapy to be added would include:

 

  1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: This is critical to suppress the overproduction of adrenal androgens. Hydrocortisone is commonly used, especially in pediatric patients, due to its short duration of action and lower impact on growth.

  2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone is usually added to manage the aldosterone deficiency, which is contributing to the hyperkalemia and hyponatremia.

  3. Sodium Chloride Supplements: In some cases, especially in infants and young children, additional sodium chloride supplements may be necessary to manage hyponatremia.

  4. Monitoring and Adjustment: Regular monitoring of electrolytes, blood pressure, and growth is necessary to adjust therapy accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Potassium Binding Resins: While these can be used to treat hyperkalemia, they do not address the underlying cause of the electrolyte imbalance in this scenario, which is likely due to aldosterone deficiency. Therefore, it would not be the first choice.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This is used primarily for heart failure and certain arrhythmias, not for the conditions described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Calcium Gluconate: This is used in the acute management of severe hyperkalemia to stabilize cardiac membranes. While it might be used in an emergency setting for life-threatening hyperkalemia, it does not address the underlying cause in this case and is not a long-term management strategy.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone (option a), as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone, as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/314

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic drug. It also produces sedation and adverse effects like dry mouth and hypotension. All these actions result due to action on which of the following receptors?(INICET MAY 2024)

 

1. D2 and 5HT2 receptors

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic receptors

3. Muscarinic and alpha-adrenergic receptors

4. H1 receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Chlorpromazine is a typical anti-psychotic drug having main mechanism of antipsychotic action as D2 blockade and minor as 5 HT2 blockade. However, it also blocks many other receptors that can result in adverse effects.

 

While chlorpromazine does block H1 receptors causing sedation, it is not the sole receptor responsible for its adverse effects. It must be considered in conjunction with D2, 5HT2, muscarinic, and alpha-adrenergic receptors.

 

Other Option:

 

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic Receptors: Chlorpromazine does not primarily act on GABA or beta-adrenergic receptors, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of anti-psychotic drugs

 

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/470-471

questions.text: A bank employee, felt depressed with no interest in activities, came to AIIMS OPD. He was started on escitalopram. Which of these adverse effects cannot be explained with escitalopram? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea, or excessive saliva production, is not a common side effect of SSRIs like escitalopram. It is more commonly associated with the atypical antipsychotic drug clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia, or difficulty achieving orgasm, is a well-known side effect of SSRIs due to their impact on serotonin levels, which can interfere with sexual function.

 

Option C. Nausea: Nausea is one of the most common side effects of SSRIs. It typically occurs at the beginning of treatment and may subside with continued use.

 

Option D. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams are another common side effect of SSRIs. They occur due to the influence of increased serotonin levels on sleep patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Escitalopram is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI).
  • Other SSRIs include Fluoxetine, Paroxetine, Fluvoxamine etc.
  • Side-effects of SSRI include:
  • Most common: Nausea, Vomiting
  • Next most common: Anxiety etc.
  • Other side effects- Delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, diarrhea, vivid dreams etc.
  • Main drug which causes sialorrhea is CLOZAPINE (an atypical anti-psychotic drug)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/488

questions.text: There was outbreak of MRSA in the hospital, and it was found that a nurse of NICU had MRSA colonization of anterior nares. What is the best treatment?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Topical mupirocin

 

  • Anterior nares are the most common site of colonization in carrier state of MRSA.
  • Mupirocin (2% topical cream) is DOC for MRSA carriers. Other drug that can be used is topical Bacitracin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral Vancomycin: Vancomycin is typically used for systemic MRSA infections and is administered intravenously due to poor oral absorption. It is not appropriate for eradicating nasal colonization.

 

Option C. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is used for multi-drug-resistant gram-negative infections and is not indicated for MRSA, especially not for nasal colonization.

 

Option D. IV cefazolin: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin effective against methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) but not MRSA. It is also not suitable for treating nasal colonization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For MRSA colonization in the anterior nares, topical mupirocin is the best treatment due to its targeted action, efficacy, and minimal systemic side effects.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/809

choices.text: b, d and e only
c and e only
a and c only
Only e is correct

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about drug resistant malaria: (AIIMS May 2019)

 

  1. It is not present in India.
  2. Quinine with clindamycin or doxycycline is still effective treatment.
  3. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective.
  4. Artemether with lumefantrine is useful.
  5. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is not useful due to high risk of recrudescence.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. b, d and e only

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum is now the most common cause of malaria as well as most common cause of drug resistant malaria in India (Option a is false)
  • DOC for multiple drug resistant P falciparum is artemisinin compounds, but they are short acting. The short action is responsible for recrudescence when used as monotherapy in malaria. So they are combined with long acting drugs (known as ACT; Artemisinin based Combination Therapy) like 
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North-Eastern states.
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine/Pyrimethamine: DOC all over India except NE states.
  • Artemisinin’s are contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy; but can be given in second and third trimester.
  • So, if drug resistant malaria occurs in 1st trimester of pregnancy, DOC is Quinine. To reduce its toxicity, we commonly add clindamycin (in pregnancy and children) or doxycycline (in other patients).
  • Chloroquine is not effective in drug resistant malaria. So artesunate (not Chloroquine) is combined with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (Option c)  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is not present in India. False. Drug-resistant malaria is present in India. Plasmodium falciparum, known for drug resistance, is a common cause of malaria in India.

 

Option C. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective. False. Chloroquine is not effective in drug-resistant malaria. Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug-resistant malaria in India is effectively treated with ACTs like Artemether with lumefantrine. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is avoided due to the risk of recrudescence.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/876-877

choices.text: Increases urine output
Increases mean arterial blood pressure

questions.text: A patient of septicemia was treated with norepinephrine infusion. Which of the following best parameter is used to monitor the effect of therapy? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Increases mean arterial blood pressure

 

Norepinephrine/ Noradrenaline, is a vasopressor commonly used in the management of septic shock. It works primarily by stimulating α1 and α2 adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction and an increase in systemic vascular resistance. It also stimulates β1 receptors, which increases cardiac output.

 

  • Increase in Mean Arterial Blood Pressure (MAP): The primary goal of using norepinephrine in septic shock is to improve perfusion by increasing MAP. Monitoring MAP is essential because it provides a direct measure of the pressure needed to ensure adequate blood flow to organs. An increase in MAP indicates improved perfusion and is a key indicator of the efficacy of norepinephrine therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradycardia: Bradycardia can occur as a reflex response to the increase in blood pressure caused by norepinephrine. However, it is not a primary parameter for monitoring the therapeutic effect of norepinephrine in septic shock.

 

Option B. Tachycardia: Tachycardia is not typically expected with norepinephrine therapy and can be a sign of other issues or a compensatory response. It is not a direct indicator of norepinephrine efficacy.

 

Option C. Increases urine output: While increased urine output is a good sign of improved renal perfusion and overall hemodynamic status, it is a secondary measure. The primary aim is to stabilize the patient's blood pressure, making MAP the more direct parameter to monitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noradrenaline acts on the α1, α2 and β1 receptors. It leads to an increase in the SBP, a rise in DBP and therefore a rise in MAP. This helps in improving the perfusion in patients suffering from septic shock. The rise in mean arterial pressure also causes reflex bradycardia but it is not a major contributor to the treatment of septic shock

questions.text: Ceftriaxone 180 mg is required for a patient. You're using a 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per ml. Ceftriaxone 500 mg/5ml is contained in the vial. How many divisions will you fill in the 2 mL syringe to give 180 mg ceftriaxone? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 18

 

In a vial of Ceftriaxone, it is given than 500mg is there in 5ml.

 

Therefore 180 mg will be present in 1.8 ml.

 

In the 2ml syringe there are 10 divisions per ml.

 

Thus, to take 1.8ml, we need to fill 10*1.8 = 18 divisions.

 

Educational Objective:


To administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone using a 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per ml, you need to fill the syringe to 18 divisions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prodrug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Primidone

 

  • Prodrugs are drugs that are present in their inactive form and are converted to the active form in the body after undergoing metabolism.
  • Among the given options primidone is not a prodrug. Although it produces active metabolites like phenobarbitone and phenylethylmalonamide (PEMA) but it cannot be considered as a prodrug because primidone itself is also active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proguanil: Proguanil is a prodrug and its active metabolite is cycloguanil. It is used in the treatment and prevention of malaria.

 

Option C. Sulindac: Sulindac is a sulfoxide prodrug used in inflammatory diseases including osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Option D. Flurouracil: Flurouracil  is a prodrug having the active metabolite as fluorouridine monophosphate. It is an anticancer chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primidone is not a prodrug because it is pharmacologically active in its original form, although it also produces active metabolites. Prodrugs like Proguanil, Sulindac, and 5-Fluorouracil require metabolic activation to exert their therapeutic effects.
